awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Linking slip dynamics to off-fault deformation in strike-slip fault systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The release of stored energy along large-scale faults, such as the San Andreas fault, can occur abruptly in an earthquake. But this stored energy can also be released via steady, periodic releases of energy known as "slow earthquakes", as well as through deformation in the regions around the fault. This project examines whether changes in how a fault moves or "slips" are linked to observable changes in the deformation of the regions around the fault. Physical experiments in a laboratory are used to replicate aspects of the San Andreas fault system to isolate individual factors controlling deformation and to understand the relationship between how a fault slips and where deformation occurs. Understanding how deformation is distributed between a fault itself and the surrounding regions is critical for forecasting regional earthquake hazards. This multi-institution project supports five students (high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels), and develops new computational tools for visualizing experimental results, along with curricular activities for middle school Earth Science courses.

The geological motivation for this project stems from observations from central California, flanking the San Andreas fault system, where slip behavior changes along the strike of the fault, and the style of off-fault deformation appears to change near the transition in slip behavior. However, naturally deforming systems are complicated, and it is difficult to show causation between slip behavior and borderland deformation. To simplify the problem, this project incorporates a series of physical experiments in the laboratory, where boundary conditions and material properties are controlled. This approach facilitates the evaluation of (1) patterns in off-fault deformation, (2) how geologic structures develop, (3) whether the system reaches a steady-state geometry, (4) whether the rate of slip impacts patterns of deformation, and (5) whether certain structures might be diagnostic of slip control. The model results may provide guidelines for characteristic structures to look for in the borderlands of lithospheric-scale faults to demonstrate slip control of off-fault deformation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit:

The geological motivation for this project stems from observations adjacent to the San Andreas fault in central California where the style of off-fault or borderland deformation appears to change near the transition in slip from creeping to locked. This project was seeking to link these two aspects of lithospheric-scale faults—their slip behavior and their borderland deformation—to investigate if and how the former controls the latter. Understanding how plate boundary deformation is distributed between on- and off-fault areas is important for seismic hazard forecasting. However, this naturally deforming system is complicated and links between slip behavior and borderland deformation are circumstantial.

Physical experiments are ideal for simplifying problems from the natural world to their most fundamental components. In this environment, the boundary conditions and material properties are controlled and only one aspect of deformation can be investigated: the transition in slip. We designed experiments to see if and how a change in slip behavior affects the style and magnitude of off-fault deformation. The experiments revealed a systematic pattern of topographic highs and lows emerging at the transition from creeping to locked slip along a strike slip fault. We used these patterns to compare to surface expressions along the San Andreas fault resulting in the identification of a topographic ‘fingerprint’ that coincides with the slip transition along a strike slip fault. This fingerprint was confirmed on three other strike-slip faults where a slip transition is documented. Besides the topography we also compared the velocity field generated by the experiments to the velocity field obtained through GPS measurements along the San Andreas fault. GPS measurements are an essential tool for monitoring faults and quantifying strain in the crust. However, to generate velocity maps interpolation between the data points is essential. The high resolution of the experiments makes them the perfect tool to test interpolation methods commonly used for the generation of velocity maps from GPS data. We re-examined the strain maps along the San Andreas fault and were able to quantify the uncertainty of the strain rate map.

This project led to two outcomes that may be of use to the wider community, including experimentalists and field scientists. First, freely available tools for analyzing and comparing velocity fields generated from experiments and GPS data. Second, the experiment results revealed a characteristic structure to look for in the borderlands of lithospheric-scale faults to indicate the transition from locked to creeping slip indicating the control of slip dynamics on off-fault deformation.

Broader impact:

This grant has supported a PhD student including tuition, stipend, and benefits through their tenure at ISU ending in a successful defense. Five undergraduate students from Carleton College were spending the summers at ISU to conduct experiments that were linked to the research efforts of this project. This experience provided them each a senior-thesis topic and experience at an R1 institution. Further, as part of an existing program at ISU, two high-school students from underrepresented groups in STEM joined the lab at ISU for one month each summer.

We developed a middle school earth science teaching module including small hands-on experiments about seismic hazards and the San Andreas fault in collaboration with Alyssa Howlett a ninth-grade teacher at Ankeny Highschool. The teaching module is designed to meet 2019-2020 Next Generation Science Standards, which focus on the human aspects of plate tectonics, natural hazards, and mitigation strategies. The teaching module have been used during the past four years and will remain part of the curriculum. 

Efforts supported by this grant will lead to three peer-reviewed publications and four presentations at national and international conferences.

 


Last Modified: 09/06/2023
Modified by: Jacqueline E Reber
